title: Police: Memory card found in street had video of woman's killing. A man has been charged
text:
CLOSE

Police in Alaska arrested a man on murder charges after a citizen reported finding a memory card that contained videos and images of a woman's assault and slaying.

Anchorage police arrested Brian Steven Smith, 48, Tuesday on murder charges after an investigation into the SD card and its contents, according to a statement from the Anchorage Police Department. The card was found Sept. 30 on a street in a residential neighborhood.

The memory card was labeled “Homicide at midtown Marriott,” the Anchorage Daily News reports, citing a police affidavit.

The card contained 39 images and 12 videos, according to charging documents. The documents say the videos show the woman being strangled, with a man's voice in one saying "just ... die."

On Thursday, police identified Kathleen J. Henry, 30, as the victim in the video and images on the SD card, according to a statement. In its statement on Wednesday, the Anchorage Police Department said they believe Henry's remains were found Oct. 2.

According the APD's statement, the crime took place during the first week of September. The Anchorage Police Department obtained a warrant for Smith's arrest Monday after an investigation and he was arrested at Ted Stevens International Airport in Anchorage.

Brian Steven Smith is shown being arraigned on a charge of first-degree murder at the Anchorage Jail courtroom Wednesday, Oct. 9, 2019, in Anchorage, Alaska. Smith was in custody after videos were found on a digital memory card depicting a woman being assaulted and killed, police in Alaska said Wednesday. (Loren Holmes/Anchorage Daily News via AP) (Photo: Loren Holmes, AP)

He was held in jail on an outstanding warrant.

Police remembered Smith from a separate investigation, a charging document says . APD spokesman M.J. Thim said Smith lives in Anchorage but is from South Africa.

"The Anchorage Police Department extends its gratitude to the citizen who stepped forward with the evidence of this crime," the APD said in a statement. "They played an instrumental role in making sure Smith will be held accountable for his actions."

Contributing: Joel Shannon; The Associated Press
